title.value: Coordination among leaf and fine root traits across a strong natural soil fertility gradient
title.justification: This is the main title provided at the beginning of the document.
title.quote: Coordination among leaf and fine root traits across a strong natural soil fertility gradient

extractions.description: This research investigates how variations in leaf and root traits among different plant species are coordinated and influenced by soil fertility, specifically along a 2-million-year soil chronosequence.

type.justification: The study involves empirical data collection and analysis of leaf and root traits across various soil fertility stages.
type.quote: We studied leaf and root trait variation among 23 co-occurring plant species along a 2-million year soil chronosequence to assess how leaf and root traits coordinate and how this resulting joint axis of variation relates to soil fertility.

name.justification: The paper focuses on plant traits, their ecological strategies, and their relations with soil fertility.
name.quote: Evaluating how fundamental axes of trait variation - describing strategies ranging from those supporting rapid growth to survival - coordinate between leaves, influencing nutrient use, and fine roots, influencing nutrient acquisition, is crucial for enhancing our understanding of plant functioning and distribution along environmental gradients, including soil fertility (Reich, 2014).

name.justification: The paper discusses plant traits related to their physiological roles and ecological contexts.
name.quote: This trade-off has been reported widely in different studies on leaf traits, across and within biomes (e.g., Reich et al., 1992; Wright et al., 2004).

name.justification: The study's dataset includes measurements taken along the Warren chronosequence, which provides a soil age gradient.
name.quote: Sampling took place from September to December 2016 along the Warren dune chronosequence, located in d’Entrecasteaux National Park in Western Australia.

referenced_paper_title.quote: For reference, the dune systems under study correspond to dune stages 1, 2, 3, 4 and 6 in the study by Turner et al. (2018).

name.quote: All statistical analyses were performed in the R environment (R Core Team, 2020).
